childhood_context.html:
Childhood: {{BIRTH_YEAR}}-{{CHILDHOOD_END_YEAR}}

You were born the year everyone thought computers would end civilization. They didn't. Y2K turned out to be the most expensive non-event in history—billions spent fixing a bug that mostly just rolled the calendar over like any other day. Welcome to the world: the apocalypse is always imminent, and usually doesn't show up.

You were one year old when 9/11 happened. You don't remember it, but you grew up in its shadow. The before-time—airports without TSA theater, casual patriotism without performative nationalism, a country that hadn't discovered it was afraid—is something you know about but never experienced. Your entire childhood was post-9/11 America, which is to say: security lines, two endless wars, and a vague sense that bad things could happen at any moment.

Your early years were the last gasp of pre-smartphone childhood. You had a few years of playing outside until the streetlights came on, of Saturday morning cartoons with actual commercial breaks, of getting bored without a screen to save you. Then the iPhone arrived when you were seven, and everything changed. You straddled the line—old enough to remember life before smartphones, young enough that they shaped your entire adolescence.

You watched your parents navigate the 2008 financial crisis from a kid's-eye view. Maybe they lost a job, maybe they just got stressed and quiet. You probably understood more than they thought you did. Kids always do. The recession was background radiation for your elementary school years—adults worried about money, things getting tighter, the nebulous understanding that the grown-ups didn't have everything figured out.

Your childhood toys were transitional. You might have had a Game Boy, then a DS, then maybe an early iPhone. You watched DVDs, then streamed on Netflix (which still mailed DVDs when you were born). You learned cursive, but you type faster than you write. You're the last generation that remembers when the internet was something you 'got on' rather than something you lived inside.

generational_identity.html:
Your Generation: Gen Z

You're Generation Z, born between 1997 and 2012. The oldest Zoomers were born the year Princess Diana died; the youngest were born the year Instagram launched. It's a wide range. You're on the older edge, which means you remember things your younger generational siblings don't: a world before TikTok, before Snapchat, before the smartphone was an extension of your hand.

Generational labels are imperfect, but here's what the data says: Gen Z is the most diverse generation in American history. You're also the most educated, though that comes with the most debt. You grew up with school shootings as a regular occurrence, lockdown drills as normal as fire drills. Columbine happened before you were born; Sandy Hook happened when you were twelve. By high school, 'thoughts and prayers' had become a bitter joke.

Your generation is often called 'digital natives,' which is accurate but incomplete. You're not just comfortable with technology—you're skeptical of it. You watched Millennials get addicted to social media and learned from their mistakes. You understand that Instagram is fake, that algorithms manipulate you, that tech companies sell your data. You use the tools anyway because there's no real alternative, but you're not naive about what they cost.

Compared to Millennials, you're more pragmatic and less optimistic. They believed the system could be fixed. You assume it's broken and work around it. They graduated into the 2008 recession and hoped things would improve. You graduated into COVID and didn't bother hoping. This isn't nihilism—it's adaptation. You're building your own structures because the existing ones weren't made for you.

Your generation is redefining everything from gender to work to success. You're less interested in climbing corporate ladders and more interested in not being miserable. You've watched older generations burn out and decided maybe that's not the goal. Mental health isn't shameful to you—it's just health. Therapy isn't weakness—it's maintenance. You're surprisingly well-adjusted for a generation raised on economic anxiety and active shooter drills.

pop_culture.html:
Pop Culture Touchstones

You were born the year Gladiator won Best Picture and *NSYNC's 'Bye Bye Bye' was everywhere. The boy band era was in full swing, Britney Spears was at peak Britney, and Christina Aguilera was getting 'Dirrty.' You don't remember this firsthand, but the cultural residue shaped everything that came after.

Your early childhood was peak Disney Channel: That's So Raven, Kim Possible, Lizzie McGuire. By elementary school, you were watching Hannah Montana learn that fame comes at a cost—a lesson the internet would teach your entire generation in real time. High School Musical convinced millions of kids that spontaneous choreography was normal. It wasn't, but the songs still slap.

Your middle school years belonged to the iPhone era. Suddenly everyone had a camera, and everyone was documenting everything. You got your first smartphone around {{TEEN_START}}, give or take. Instagram launched when you were ten. Vine launched when you were twelve. You were the target demographic for content that lasted six seconds because attention spans were already fragmenting.

Music in your formative years: Lady Gaga made weird mainstream. Taylor Swift transitioned from country to world domination. Kanye West was still making music people could enjoy without moral calculus. By high school, streaming had killed the album. You listened to playlists, not records. The idea of buying music physically seemed as quaint as rotary phones.

Your generation's cultural references are different from every generation before because you all watched different things. There's no show everyone saw, no album everyone owned, no movie everyone watched in theaters together. Culture splintered into algorithmic niches. You bond over memes, not media. Your cultural touchstones are TikTok sounds and Twitter moments that last a week before being replaced by the next thing.

The pop culture you grew up with was exhausting—constant, overwhelming, disposable. But it also taught you something valuable: nothing lasts, virality is arbitrary, and the thing everyone's talking about today will be forgotten by next month. This makes you weirdly resilient. You don't expect permanence. You've been trained for ephemerality.

technology.html:
Your Technology Timeline

You were born into the dot-com bubble, which burst spectacularly a few months after you arrived. All those sock puppet mascots and 'eyeballs before profits' startups imploded. It was the first tech crash of your lifetime. It wouldn't be the last. The industry would recover, overcorrect, and crash again in different ways. You've never known technology as stable.

The iPhone launched when you were seven—old enough to remember life before it, young enough to have your adolescence shaped by it. You're not like Millennials, who got smartphones as adults, or the younger Gen Z kids who never knew anything else. You're the transition generation. You remember boredom. You remember not being reachable. You remember the freedom and terror of being truly alone with your thoughts.

Social media arrived in stages. Facebook was for old people by the time you were old enough to use it. Instagram was your first real platform—filtered photos, curated lives, the beginning of performing your existence for an audience. Snapchat added ephemerality; suddenly your posts could disappear, which felt like freedom. TikTok arrived in your late teens and consumed everything. The algorithm knew you better than you knew yourself.

You learned to code—or at least learned what coding was—earlier than any previous generation. Your school probably had STEM initiatives, coding camps, robotics clubs. Whether you participated or not, technology wasn't mysterious. It was just infrastructure. You've never been impressed by someone knowing how to use a computer. That's like being impressed someone knows how to open a door.

Your relationship with technology is complicated. You know it's manipulating you. You know the attention economy extracts value from your eyeballs. You know that 'free' services are paid for with your data. But you use them anyway because the alternative—being disconnected—feels impossible. You've optimized for awareness without agency. You know the game is rigged but you're playing it anyway.

AI became conversational during your early twenties. ChatGPT launched, and suddenly the robots could write your emails. By the time you're thirty, AI will be integrated into everything. You'll be the generation that saw artificial intelligence go from science fiction to mundane tool. Your kids won't remember when computers couldn't talk back.

historical_milestones.html:
Historical Milestones

You were one year old during 9/11. You have no memory of it, but you grew up in the world it created. The TSA, the Patriot Act, the wars in Afghanistan and Iraq—this was normal to you. America at war was your childhood's background noise. The 'forever wars' started before you could walk and ended (sort of) when you were in your twenties.

Hurricane Katrina hit when you were five. You probably don't remember it directly, but it was the first time your generation saw the government fail spectacularly in real-time on television. Bodies floating, people stranded on rooftops, a president who seemed disconnected. It was a preview of coming attractions: the climate disasters that would define your adulthood.

The 2008 financial crisis hit when you were eight. You didn't understand credit default swaps or mortgage-backed securities, but you understood that adults were scared. Maybe your parents lost jobs, lost homes, lost stability. The recovery was slow and uneven. By the time you were old enough to enter the workforce, the scars were still visible.

Obama's election happened when you were eight. A Black president was normal to you in a way it wasn't for older generations. Then Trump happened when you were sixteen, and suddenly the adults who'd told you racism was over couldn't explain what was happening. You watched the country reveal itself, and it wasn't pretty.

School shootings punctuated your education. Sandy Hook happened when you were twelve. Parkland happened when you were seventeen—and this time, the kids fought back. March For Our Lives was your generation's first major political mobilization. You learned that outrage doesn't equal change, but you also learned that silence guarantees defeat.

COVID hit when you were twenty. If you were in college, you got sent home mid-semester. If you were entering the workforce, the workforce disappeared. Graduation ceremonies were canceled or conducted via Zoom. The pandemic compressed years of change into months: remote work, remote school, remote everything. You lost time you won't get back—formative years of parties not attended, connections not made, experiences not had.

Climate change went from abstract future threat to present reality during your lifetime. Wildfires, floods, heat domes, polar vortexes—the weather got weird and kept getting weirder. By your twenties, climate anxiety was just anxiety. The planet was warming and nobody with power was doing enough. You've internalized this. It colors everything.

career.html:
Career & Professional Life

You entered the workforce around 2022, which means you graduated into... whatever that was. The pandemic hangover. The Great Resignation. The weird economy where unemployment was low but so were real wages, and everyone was hiring but nobody was paying. Welcome to your career: it started confusing and shows no signs of clarifying.

Remote work is normal to you in ways it isn't for older workers. You don't romanticize the office. You've seen how much time commuting wastes, how many meetings could have been emails, how much 'collaboration' is actually surveillance. You want flexibility because you've seen that the work gets done either way, and sitting in a cubicle doesn't make you more productive.

Your generation is skeptical of hustle culture. You watched Millennials burn out chasing the dream, posting inspirational quotes about grinding while their mental health collapsed. You're not interested in being a girlboss or a founder bro. You want reasonable hours, decent pay, and a life outside of work. This isn't laziness—it's learning from others' mistakes.

Side hustles are normal to you, but not because you find them empowering. You do them because one job often isn't enough. You've seen the gig economy's promise ('be your own boss!') and its reality ('no benefits, no stability, algorithmic tyranny'). You understand that flexibility often means exploitation with better PR.

The jobs of your childhood don't exist anymore. The jobs you'll have at forty don't exist yet. AI is coming for white-collar work the way automation came for manufacturing. Your generation will have to adapt constantly—reskilling, pivoting, staying relevant in a labor market that's being disrupted faster than anyone can track. This is exhausting to contemplate, which is why you mostly don't.

What you want from work is different from what previous generations wanted. Boomers wanted stability. Gen X wanted independence. Millennials wanted meaning. You want honesty. Just tell you what the job is, pay you fairly, and don't pretend it's a family. You'll do the work. Just don't insult your intelligence with corporate buzzwords while you're doing it.

relationships.html:
Relationships & Communication

You've never known dating without apps. Sure, you could theoretically meet someone 'in the wild,' but the infrastructure of modern courtship is digital. Swipe right, match, text for days before meeting, repeat. You've normalized the paradox of infinite choice leading to decision paralysis. When everyone is available, no one feels special.

Your generation communicates differently. You text, obviously, but texting feels formal compared to DMs, Snaps, and TikTok comments. You have different communication channels for different intimacy levels. A phone call is either very serious or very weird. FaceTime is for close friends and family. You've developed an entire semiotics around response times, emoji usage, and read receipts.

You're surprisingly traditional in some ways. Studies show Gen Z actually wants long-term relationships, marriage, kids—the conventional milestones. You're just practical about the obstacles. Marriage costs money. Kids cost more. Housing is impossible. You want the life your grandparents had; you just can't afford it.

Friendship in your generation is maintained digitally across distance in ways that weren't possible before. Your best friend might live in another state. You've bonded with people you've never met in person. Online relationships are real relationships. The people who dismiss internet friends as fake don't understand that you've grown up with the internet as a social space, not just a tool.

You're more open about mental health in relationships than previous generations. You talk about boundaries, attachment styles, therapy. You've normalized saying 'I need space' or 'that triggered me.' Some older people find this excessive. You find it honest. You'd rather address problems than pretend they don't exist.

Your generation is redefining what relationships look like. Traditional timelines—date, engaged, married, kids—feel less mandatory. Some of you want that path. Some want something different. The expectation that everyone follows the same script has loosened, which is liberating if you're outside the norm and overwhelming if you liked having a script to follow.

financial.html:
Financial Psychology

You were eight during the 2008 financial crisis. You don't remember the details, but you remember the vibes: stressed parents, foreclosure signs, the sense that money was scary and unpredictable. Your financial psychology was shaped before you had any money to manage.

College, if you went, came with debt. Average student loan debt for your cohort is around $30,000, though plenty of you have more. You were told education was the path to success, then handed a bill that will follow you for decades. The math doesn't work, but the alternatives—no degree, fewer opportunities—seem worse. You're paying for a credential that depreciated before you finished earning it.

Housing feels impossible. Home prices have outpaced wages for your entire adult life. The median home costs more than ever relative to median income. Your parents might have bought a house in their twenties. You're watching from your rental, doing the math, realizing it doesn't add up. Homeownership has shifted from expectation to aspiration to fantasy.

Your generation saves, but not for retirement. You save for emergencies because you've seen how fast things fall apart. You keep a buffer because the safety net has holes. Traditional financial advice—invest early, compound interest, retire at 65—assumes stability you've never experienced. You're planning for uncertainty because certainty isn't available.

You're surprisingly financially literate, partly because you had to be. You learned about investing from TikTok and Reddit. You understand meme stocks are gambling but gambled anyway because what's the alternative, a savings account that loses to inflation? The traditional financial system doesn't work for you, so you've built parallel systems—some smart, some reckless, all interesting.

Your financial goals are different from your parents'. They wanted accumulation: house, cars, retirement account. You want freedom: enough money to not be trapped, enough flexibility to walk away from bad situations. You're not dreaming of wealth; you're dreaming of security. In a precarious world, security is the luxury.

blind_spots.html:
Your Generational Blind Spots

Your generation's biggest blind spot is assuming everyone has the same access to information you do. You grew up with the internet, so you assume competence is just a YouTube tutorial away. But not everyone learns that way. Not everyone has the same digital literacy. Your generation can be accidentally condescending to people who struggle with things you find intuitive.

You're so attuned to systemic problems that you sometimes miss individual agency. Everything is structural to you—capitalism, patriarchy, white supremacy, ableism. These systems are real and worth critiquing. But sometimes the problem is also that one specific person made a bad choice. Both can be true. Your generation's analytical framework can become a way of avoiding personal responsibility.

You're chronically online in ways that distort your perception of reality. The discourse on Twitter is not the country. TikTok trends are not culture. The takes you see are curated by algorithms to maximize engagement, which means outrage and conflict. You know this intellectually, but it's hard to feel it when you're scrolling. Your worldview is shaped by what gets amplified, and what gets amplified isn't what's typical.

You're conflict-averse in person while being conflict-fluent online. You can argue fiercely in comments but freeze in face-to-face confrontation. This is a problem because power isn't negotiated in comment sections. The people who control things—boards, legislatures, boardrooms—meet in person. Digital activism matters, but it's not sufficient. At some point you have to show up physically, and that's harder for a generation trained on screens.

Your generation sometimes mistakes information for action. You're well-informed about problems—climate change, inequality, injustice—but information doesn't equal impact. Knowing about a problem doesn't solve it. Sharing an infographic doesn't change policy. Your generation has the awareness; what's less clear is whether you have the follow-through to translate awareness into sustained, boring, institutional change.

You've inherited irony as a defense mechanism, which makes earnestness feel risky. Caring too much about something is cringe. Admitting you want things—success, love, meaning—feels vulnerable. So you couch everything in jokes and layers of distance. This protects you from disappointment, but it also prevents connection. At some point, you have to drop the irony and mean what you say. That's scarier than it sounds.

life_roadmap.html:
Life Phase Roadmap

Your 20s ({{TWENTIES_START}}-{{TWENTIES_END}}): You're in this decade now, and it's weird. You graduated into a pandemic, entered a job market that couldn't decide if it was booming or collapsing, and you're trying to build a life while everything feels unstable. Traditional milestones—career progression, relationships, housing—are happening on delayed timelines if they're happening at all. This is supposed to be your foundation-building decade, but the ground keeps shifting. The best you can do is stay adaptable, build skills that transfer, and try not to compare yourself to timelines that no longer apply.

Your 30s ({{THIRTIES_START}}-{{THIRTIES_END}}): By your thirties, the chaos of your twenties should consolidate into something more stable. Emphasis on 'should.' You'll probably have a clearer career direction, even if it's not what you expected. Relationships—romantic, platonic, familial—will matter more as you realize life is long and lonely without them. If you want kids, this is statistically when most people have them. If you don't want kids, this is when you'll get tired of explaining that choice. This decade is about choosing what you're building toward, knowing you can't have everything.

Your 40s ({{FORTIES_START}}-{{FORTIES_END}}): Peak earning years, peak responsibility. You'll probably be managing people at work, whether you want to or not. If you have kids, they'll be the age you were during your formative memories—weird to contemplate. Your parents will be aging, and you'll start dealing with their mortality in concrete ways. This is the sandwich decade: caring for generations above and below you while trying to maintain your own identity. The key skill is saying no—to obligations, to guilt, to the endless demands on your time. You can't do everything. Choosing what to prioritize is the work.

Your 50s ({{FIFTIES_START}}-{{FIFTIES_END}}): The world in your fifties will be different enough that predictions are unreliable. Climate change will have reshaped geography, economics, politics. AI will have transformed work in ways we can't fully anticipate. But some things will be constant: you'll be thinking about legacy, about what you've built and what you're leaving behind. You'll have perspective your younger self lacked—both the wisdom that comes from experience and the regrets that come from choices you can't unmake. This is the decade for mentorship, for passing on what you've learned, for making peace with who you've become.

Your 60s and beyond ({{SIXTIES_START}}+): Retirement for your generation will look nothing like your grandparents' retirement—golf and Social Security and twenty stable years. It might not be retirement at all. The economics don't support it, and the concept itself is rooted in industrial-age assumptions about work and age. What you'll have instead is transition: shifting from primary earner to something else, finding meaning outside of productivity, contending with a body that has opinions about your activities. The upside: you've never expected stability. The downside: you were right.

comparison.html:
Generational Comparison

You're part of a birth cohort of roughly 4 million people born in {{BIRTH_YEAR}}. Generation Z as a whole is about 68 million people in the US, slightly smaller than Millennials but on track to become the dominant demographic as Boomers age out. You're inheriting a country—and a planet—that previous generations shaped and, frankly, damaged.

Compared to Millennials (born 1981-1996), you're more pragmatic and less optimistic. They believed the system could be reformed. You assume it's broken and build around it. They were surprised by the 2008 crash. You were shaped by it. They remember the before-times; you grew up in the after. The differences are subtle but real: you're more skeptical, more adaptable, less likely to be disappointed because you expected less to begin with.

Compared to Gen X (born 1965-1980), you have almost nothing in common except a shared irony and distrust of institutions. They were latchkey kids who became slackers who became middle managers. You're digital natives who became content creators who became... whatever comes next. They had the privilege of being ignored; you have the burden of being watched, always, by algorithms and peers alike.

Compared to Boomers (born 1946-1964), the wealth gap is obscene. They controlled about 21% of national wealth at your age. Your generation controls roughly 4%. They bought houses on single incomes. You're splitting rent with roommates in your late twenties. They had pensions, union jobs, affordable education, and they voted to dismantle all of that before you could vote to keep it. The intergenerational transfer of wealth is not going in your direction.

Your life expectancy is uncertain. Previous generations could assume roughly eighty years. Your generation might get more—medical advances—or might get less—climate change, inequality, deaths of despair. You've grown up with the knowledge that the future is not guaranteed, which is psychologically different from previous generations who assumed progress was inevitable.

But here's the thing: every generation thinks it's special, and every generation is wrong. You'll make the same mistakes as those who came before, just in new forms. You'll eventually become the older generation that younger people blame for their problems. The cycle continues. What matters isn't being different from other generations—it's figuring out how to live well despite the hand you were dealt. That's not unique to you. That's everyone, always.

year_events: Y2K turned out to be a non-event
Bush v. Gore went to the Supreme Court
The first season of Survivor aired
